NOTES: Founding members of the main rebel Congolese Rally for Democracy (RCD) ousted Congolese rebel leader Ernest Wamba dia Wamba and named Emile Ilunga as their new leader in an attempt to resolve internal divisions that have beset the movement for months. NOTES: Military convoys pass over the border bridges of Ruzizi One and Two of at least 10 military trucks each day, carrying soldiers of the regular army of Kigali, arriving from nearby Rwanda towards the eastern region of Kivu: Military convoys which on arrival in the city of Bukavu divided on two routes: northwest in the direction of Bunyakiri (80 km from Bukavu) and southwest in direction of Walungu (40 km from Bukavu). The convoys have been being attacked regularly by Kabila's government troops and Mai-Mai forces- no confirmations on death tolls, although they are believed to be very high.

NOTES: Ndaheba Rusagara, president of the Mediation and Defence Committee (CMD), local organization for the defence of human rights, was assassinated last Saturday night [30 December] in his house in Sange (40 km north of Uvira, Sud-Kivu). The FDLR was caught in a stranglehold when Mai Mai Kifwafwa [tribal militia], came out and attacked the locality of Busuringi, said Walikale authorities. FDLR overpowered the Mayi mayi and after looting and burning the area, withdrew from the Ntoto forest, some hundred kilometres from Kando.

The crowd was apparently protesting against attacks in the region carried out by Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda rebels, Nesirky told a briefing.The UN mission in DR Congo reported that "elements" of a Mai-Mai group, the Rai Mutomboki, "may have been part of the protest and may have fired on the peacekeepers," The Rai Mutomboki are an armed self-defense group.
CONSOLIDATED_NOTES: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)|MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)|A mob surrounded UN compound and some opened fire on UN Peacekeeping troops, others throwing stones. 7 Pakistani peacekeepers were injured. The crowd was apparently protesting against attacks in the region carried out by Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda rebels, Nesirky told a briefing.The UN mission in DR Congo reported that "elements" of a Mai-Mai group, the Rai Mutomboki, "may have been part of the protest and may have fired on the peacekeepers," The Rai Mutomboki are an armed self-defense group.|AFP
